transcripts.text: Guys, today I'm at the Independence Square here in Accra, Ghana.  I want to interact with our African-American brothers and sisters.  We are still talking the year of return, right?  So I want to know how far they are faring, you know, how they are enjoying Ghana, what they feel about the year of return.  So watch on, let's go and interact.  How long have you been in Ghana?
On this trip, I've been in Ghana for nine days.
Nine days.  So how has your experience been like so far?  It's been fantastic.  Fantastic.

We had a chance to go see the Nomina Castle and places where the actual transatlantic slave trade happened.  We also had a chance to just have some fun with people who flew into town to experience a good time in Accra.
Okay.  So what do you think about Ghana, the people of Ghana generally?

I think the people of Ghana are just genuinely kind-hearted, warm-hearted, beautiful people, very welcoming.  I've heard the word Akwaba maybe a thousand times.  And, you know, I think that there's a lot of opportunity here and a lot of potential.  And this place really just kind of feels like home for those of us who are coming here who may not have visited before, who are coming here just to experience the land for the first time.
Okay.  Interesting.  So what local dishes have you tried so far?
Red-red.  What?  Red-red.
Red-red.
With fish.
With fish.
The best one.
The best.

Yeah.  But plantain here is amazing.  I actually have a friend of mine who's launching a plantain chips company.  Okay.  And she's going to be exporting some of Ghanaian plantains to the United States.  Okay.  plantains, Red Red, and then, of course, Ghanaian Jollof.  There's always this debate between Ghanaian and Nigerian Jollof.  Ghanaian Jollof is doing pretty good.
Have you tried Niger Angelos?  I have.  You have?  I have.  So which is the best?
I'm not going to say this on camera.

This is not going to happen here.  Okay.  Okay.  Fair enough.  So what would you say to our African American brothers who haven't come to the motherland, haven't been here, what would you say to them?

I would say you don't know where you're going if you don't know where you're coming from.  I think you've got to visit.  You have to see.  It's part of our culture, our experience that we've been cut off from historically, intentionally.  People have been trying to disassociate us with our past, with our history, with our culture.  So you've got to come here and reconnect with us.
All right.  Thank you.  Enjoy your stay.  Thank you.  Hi.  Can I meet you?  What's your name?
My name is Rhoda.
Rhoda.  From which state?
I'm from North Carolina, United States.

I've been in Ghana for, we came here last Monday, so I've been here for almost a week and a half.

I'm really enjoying it.  I haven't been to Ghana in about 28 years.  So this is my first time coming in 28 years.  So everything has changed and I'm really enjoying it.
Enjoying it.  So what has really changed since 28 years?  Construction.
Like when I used to live here, it was a lot of, it wasn't developed that good.  But now there's more people here.  People are visiting.  Construction, roads, everything is different.
